name: (m, k)-Perfect Number
description:
Simpler and similar kata here. A generalization of perfect numbers are (m,k)-perfect number. It is a series of numbers that satisfy the following condition: ```math \Huge \sigma^{m}(n) = kn ``` where σm is the divisor function (or sum of all divisors) [Wikipedia link] applied ```m``` times, ```k``` a constant. For example "normal" perfect numbers are (1,2)-perfect number. Goal:
Write a function ```first_mk_perfectnumber(m,k)``` that, give in input the ```m``` and ```k``` of the previous equation ( σm(n) = kn ) , it returns the first number (```n```) that satisfy the relation. Pay attention to the performance of your algorithm!! This function must run within the maximum time very big number (>200000). My solution's time of execution in any language is around 4 seconds. Wikipedia Page : Superperfect Number [Generalization at bottom] Example:
```first_mk_perfectnumber(2,2)``` return 2 because
σ(σ(1)) = 1 so ```1 != 2*1``` while σ(σ(2)) = 4 so ```4 == 2*2``` Hint 1: You can execute divisor function speedly with prime factors. You can find formula here: Wiki Page Wolfram Page
